entry.title: 3ZB Billing Costs Between Companies error ME124 Material Subject to Inventory
entry.content:
Hi,

Update: My below question is resolved with help of note 3049571. When I use a finished product (material type FERT) instead of a service product (material type SERV), the purchase order, sales order, billing document and supplier invoice are processed successfully. The 3ZB test script instruction to use a service product seems to be incorrect.

I am trying to enable best practice scope item 3ZB "Billing of Costs Between Affiliated Companies" in S/4HANA Public version 2508 according to the corresponding setup guide (CBC path: Sales > Sales Business Portfolio > Intercompany Sales > Set Up Billing of Costs Between Affiliated Companies ).

When creating a Purchase Order for the service product the following error message is raised: "Material not subj. to inventory mgmt. in plant 3720 (Pl. check your input) - Message no. ME124. There is no data for plant 3720 (plant/storage location stock view) in
the material master record." Plant 3720 is the buying/receiving plant in the PO item. The supplier of the PO is another company.

This error should not happen because this scenario is about service purchasing, so inventory is not relevant.

The product is defined with material type SERV (PO Item field Product Type Group = 2 Service). SSCUI 103539 "Define Attributes of Material Types" shows that no quantity and value update take place for SERV as expected.

Account assignment of the purchase order item is cost center and goods receipt indicator is switched off.  

I noticed that the same issue was addressed in question 3ZB Billing Cost between companies is not working but unfortunately it is not explained here what solution was applied to overcome this issue "There is no data for plant XXXX (plant/storage location stock view) in the material master record". 

@HenrikeGrtecke , @adrian321 , can you please share what correction actions were taken to solve the issue?

Note 3049571 "Material Not Subj. to Inventory Mgmt. in Plant( Intercompany Stock Transfer Process with SERV in Purchase Order)" says that "in the standard system the stock transport is not possible for non-stock material types like SERV". But in the test script of scope item 3ZB SERV material SM0001 "Service Material 01" from Master Data Scripts (MDS) 31X Create Product Master of type "Service Product"  is used. Is this an error in the best practice test script?

entry.title: Integrations as part of the SAP LeanIX (Enterprise) Architecture?
entry.content:
We may have our state-of-the-art Applications. But how do we make them work together? We may have all our Date Objects properly designed and governed. But how do we unlock it for the Users and Agents?

Integration ‚Äì key is in the Integration Services!

We have to integrate Applications, Users and Agents ‚Äì in order to unlock our Data and make our Business Processes run seamlessly and efficiently, cross whole Enterprise.

I‚Äôve talked about importance of recognizing the work on integrations in the Enterprise Architecture domain (my article in SAP EA Community: Enterprise Architecture for integration?), but now let‚Äôs go with few practical examples‚Ä¶

Integrations @ EAM

If we use SAP LeanIX solutions[1] as EAM (Enterprise Architecture Management) tool, and we want to model our Enterprise Architecture ‚Äì how do we manage it, if we do not ‚Äúconnect‚Äù the dots

Well, we cannot!

Figure 1. Integration Services

Of course, integrations are far more complex than just ‚Äúconnecting‚Äù dots. In this example, I‚Äôve used an example where we replicate Business Partner Customers to two order taking channels ‚Äì fairly common scenario in Omnichannel Sales.

  • Source is Master Data System (i.e. SAP MDG) ‚Äì this is clearly marked as an Application in SAP LeanIX.(of course, we may have multiple Applications within one ‚Äúbox‚Äù, but overall object modeling is a different story, not covered by this article‚Ä¶).
  • Target Systems are B2B Channel and Field Sales ‚Äì again I am color-coding those as Applications.
  • From Source to Target Systems, we are replicating Customer ‚Äì this is Data Object.
  • Finally, we have an Interface (if we use SAP LeanIX notation), or Integration Service (in a broader sense). We may be ‚Äúhappy‚Äù in seeing ‚Äúonly‚Äù one line, representing BP Customer Replication. connecting Source and Target Systems‚Ä¶ This is probably sufficient for high-level C4[2] diagramming and modeling.
  • However, if we want more details on Interfaces (or dots ‚Äúconnecting‚Äù Applications) ‚Äì i.e. how it actually works, what are the underlying technology and capabilities, which patters were used etc. ‚Äì then we must go few levels ‚Äúbelow‚Äù in the integration hierarchy. Each ‚Äúparent‚Äù Interface (or Integration Service). has one or more ‚Äúchild‚Äù Interface Components (or Integration Service Components) ‚Äì i.e. APIs, IFlows, Queues etc.; and those ‚Äúchild‚Äù Interface Components ‚Äúuses‚Äù some IT Components ‚Äì i.e. SAP CPI, API-M, Azure Service Bus etc.

Figure 2. SAP LeanIX Interface Fact Sheet

In SAP LeanIX each object is modeled with its own Fact Sheet, thus each Interface, whether ‚Äúparent‚Äù or ‚Äúchild‚Äù, has its Fact Sheet. There are some powerful features when defining Fact Sheets:

  • We are defining descriptions, attributes, and we also have a possibility to add links to external resources ‚Äì i.e. we may have external repositories with functional and technical details in Azure DevOps Wikis or GitHub..
  • We can link Interface with its ‚Äúparent‚Äù or ‚Äúchild:
  • We can link Interfaces among themselves into ‚Äúleft/right‚Äù flow.
  • We can link with appropriate Application(s), Data Object(s) and IT Component(s)

Interesting though is to note, general recommendation in SAP LeanIX is to use Applications for Business Applications, while Technical Applications (like SAP Integration Suite etc.), enabling specific Interfaces, we should model as IT Components. Although there is no strict limitation preventing us to set i.e. SAP Integration Suite as an Application (this will of course create different pictures in C4 diagrams), the important thing is to choose the approach ‚Äúonce‚Äù and stay consistent.

Figure 3. Integration model

Object models with connected Interfaces can very easily become very complex. But do we really have a choice ‚Äì not to model full integrations? Is it sufficient to have only high-level Enterprise Architecture in EAM tool?

I guess it all depends on the preferences, but I would say ‚Äì no, it is not sufficient.

And it‚Äôs not about ‚Äì ‚Äúhey SAP LeanIX give us possibility to model Interfaces in more granularity‚Äù ‚Äì this is about overall management of the Enterprise Architecture. How can we manage something we do not see? And yes, integration is really a key, or a backbone, of daily operations of any Enterprise:

  • The Architect View(point) must include sufficient level of details on all Architectural components ‚Äì otherwise we are ‚Äúblind‚Äù in seeing AS-IS state.
  • Building new or reusing existing integrations cannot be made without appropriate visibility on the underlaying layers of the Interface(s) or Integration Service(s) ‚Äì otherwise we cannot make educated decision for TO-BE state
  • If we do not have adequate view on AS-IS and TO-BE, we cannot properly understand the Gap and build roadmap, planning and strategy.

Integrations @ EA Frameworks

Ups looks like no Integration Architecture domain in TOGAF¬©[2]?

Figure 4. Where is Integration Architecture

Where is Integration Architecture domain?

  • Is it part of B. Business Architecture? Probably not, but aren‚Äôt we saying that integrations are enabling Integrated Business Processes‚Ä¶
  • Maybe it‚Äôs part of C. Information System Architecture, also (usually) split into Application Architecture and Data Architecture? Looks reasonable to be ‚Äúsomewhere‚Äù here, but still, it‚Äôs not ‚Äúformally‚Äù listed here‚Ä¶
  • Or is it D. Technology Architecture? Integrations are often observed as ‚Äútechnology‚Äù domain, but this is not entirely correct perception‚Ä¶

Hold on, nothing is ‚Äúcarved in stone‚Äù‚Ä¶

Figure 5. LeanIX Application and Data Architecture

Interfaces (or Integration Services) should be observed on the same level as Applications and Data Objects ‚Äì and in SAP LeanIX metamodel[3], indeed we do see that Interface(s) are part of Application and Data Architecture.

  • Application ‚Äúprovides‚Äù and/or ‚Äúconsumes‚Äù Interface.
  • Interface ‚Äútransfers‚Äù Data Object.

Integrations are not just dots or lines ‚Äì it‚Äôs much more, no matter if we observe some underlaying IPaaS or Event Broker as an IT Component or an Application. And if we accept these guidelines, then we have to ‚Äúpay‚Äù attention to model integrations correctly and fully.

Simple and clear‚Ä¶

Integrations @ AI use-cases?

First ‚Äúreply‚Äù would be ‚Äì yes of course. But let‚Äôs think where we are heading with AI‚Ä¶

MCP Serves can be built on tables ‚Äì accessing Data Objects directly. It can be done, yes, but do we want this or would we prefer some sort of governance by exposing Data Objects via OData and API Management in between? That is the question yet to be answered‚Ä¶ But I know my answer. Of course, in the "world" of Microsoft Dynamic365, MCP Servers are actually based on Dataverse object or tables (not APIs) but this is different, I guess‚Ä¶

Now, what about A2A (Agent-to-Agent)? This is also some sort of integration‚Ä¶ Well, if it is integration, it is an integration ‚Äì ‚Äúthings‚Äù are not being integrated on its own... 

Why am I bringing AI? AI is now ‚Äúmixing and matching‚Äù with everything. While AI Agents and Agentic AI will most certainly impact integration technology, the need to precisely ‚Äúcraft‚Äù Integration Services will not disappear. It may change, but it will not disappear!

Putting this in the EAM perspective ‚Äì yes of course we do want to manage all out AI investments, ideally in one EAM tool, and SAP LeanIX now comes with AI agent hub[4] ‚Äì equipped to discover, manage and govern all AI agents. Of course, A2A and MCP are somehow inevitable part of it. Another reason to model integrations correctly and fully... 

Integration is the key!

Integration, whether it is fully Decoupled Integration based on Event-Driven Architecture principles supporting Compostable Business (Architecture)[5], or it is some more legacy SOA[6] ‚Äì in all cases, it is Integration Services which are making things ‚Äúhappen‚Äù.

So, it‚Äôs a glue connecting Application Blocks, right?

No, no ‚Äì it‚Äôs not ‚Äújust‚Äù a glue! It used to be a ‚Äúreal‚Äù glue ‚Äì well at least in legacy solutions, connecting monolithic ‚Äúboxes‚Äù. But now we are Agile, we are building Systems to be ‚ÄúCompossible‚Äù. If Applications are Blocks (one can imagine its LEGO¬©[7] or equivalent), we don‚Äôt want to glue Blocks, because we cannot ‚Äúrecompose‚Äù our System of Blocks into something different, we cannot change Blocks, and or try new Blocks..

This ‚Äúglue‚Äù we use is invisible it is by design ‚Äì its Blocks itself ‚Äì the way how we build them to ‚Äúfit‚Äù ‚Äì no matter of their particular shape, or size or color, they can always fit. They can fit ‚Äútight‚Äù but can be ‚Äúdisassembled‚Äù at any time we need to ‚Äúrecompose‚Äù the System of Blocks.

Sounds simple, but it‚Äôs not.

If we want that flexibility, if we want to avoid ‚Äúfixing‚Äù with glue ‚Äì we need to design and build with precision. And this is more than just technology stack ‚Äì this is also about overall strategy ‚Äì what kind of Blocks we need to connect now, or in future. How do we ‚Äúcraft‚Äù integrations so everything can fit ‚Äì not only now. but in foreseeable future as well.

Who are we?

We are Developers ‚Äì yes (this is our usual background)! We are Engineers ‚Äì yes (most certainly)! But we are seasoned Architects ‚Äì yes as well, very seasoned (if I may add)!

We are versatile Architects who need to know, or at least understand, so many different ‚Äúthings‚Äù ‚Äì not only integration technologies, but Data Models, Applications, even Business Processes. After all, we are not integrating Applications and Systems, we are integrating Business (Processes).

Figure 6. Work of EA for Integration

We can be Solution Architects or Enterprise Architect, just as in any domain ‚Äì but we must be able to understand much more than ‚Äújust‚Äù integration technology.

Is our work perceived that way? Well, this is a different story‚Ä¶

And again ‚Äì Integration Services‚Ä¶

I am being subjective ‚Äì yes. But haven‚Äôt I proved how important integration is?

Is the integration work seen and valued as any other Enterprise Architecture work? Very rarely, as integration is usually seen as very technical discipline, part of solutioning, not strategy‚Ä¶ There are exceptions (obviously)‚Ä¶ 

Maybe we need to raise the awareness and change the mindset ‚Äì proper integration modeling and design is the key for the success in many initiatives ‚Äì and proper modeling has to come as a result of the Integration Strategy, not just "technical" solutioning on case-to-case basis.  

Am I giving too much ‚Äúcredit‚Äù to integrations? Yes, but with a reason‚Ä¶ Just think, how many projects failed or were delayed because integrations were not properly designed or implemented? And this (usually) has nothing to do with ‚Äúbad‚Äù integration developers and integration engineers‚Ä¶ 

Does this resonate?

Acknowledgment

*) Into image generated by AI.

References

[1] SAP LeanIX: https://www.leanix.net/en/

[2] C4 model: https://c4model.com/

[3] SAP LeanIX Interface Modeling Guidelines: https://help.sap.com/docs/leanix/ea/interface-modeling-guidelines

[4] SAP LeanIX AI agent hub: https://www.leanix.net/en/ai-agent-hub-in-sap-leanix

[5] Composable Architecture: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/what-is-composable-architecture/ba-p/13889670

[6] SOA: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/agile-ea-from-soa-to-interoperability/ba-p/225234

[7] LEGO¬©: https://www.lego.com/

entry.title: Dynamic Quotation Attribute Analytics in SAP CPQ
entry.content:
SAP CPQ supports advanced analytics and visualization directly from your product and quotation data, enabling sales and business leaders to drive decisions with real-time insights. By leveraging SAP CPQ's scripting capabilities, users can programmatically query system tables, such as context.Quote or Quote and Product, to aggregate key attribute data‚Äîfor example, tracking the number of quotes generated for different product types or configurations.

 

How to Generate Analytics and Graphs

To produce meaningful visualizations, use the following approach:

  • Query product and quotation data: Use scripting (IronPython) within SAP CPQ to run queries against system tables. For instance, fetch the count of quotations grouped by a specific product attribute (like type or power rating) for each quarter.

  • Assemble data for visualization: Transform the queried results into chart-ready arrays representing, for example, quarterly counts for each product configuration.

  • Integrate with visualization services: Use an API like QuickChart to render a bar chart. Script-generated data can be sent to the QuickChart REST API, returning a chart image that can be embedded in quote dashboards, emails, or management reports.

 

quickchart_url = 'https://quickchart.io/chart/create'
post_data = {
    'chart': {
        'type': 'bar',
        'data': {
            'labels': ['Q1', 'Q2', 'Q3', 'Q4'],
            'datasets': [
                {'label': 'Centrifugal', 'data': [70, 95, 89, 104]},
                {'label': 'Submersible', 'data': [40, 30, 38, 42]},
                {'label': 'Gear', 'data': [12, 18, 22, 17]}
            ]
        }
    }
}

response = RestClient.Post(quickchart_url, post_data)


After running the Python or SAP CPQ server-side code to generate your chart using the QuickChart API, the API response contains a URL where the rendered graph can be accessed.

You can use this URL in any document or reporting output. For instance, if you need to embed the chart in a generated HTML document or email from SAP CPQ, simply include an HTML image tag like this:

<img width='800px' height='400px' id='lineChart' src="https://quickchart.io/chart/render/sf-610928f3-3854-4266-a8ea-6fc6d8662ce6">

This approach allows you to dynamically visualize attribute-based analytics (such as quote counts by pump type, quarter, or any product dimension) within your business documents, dashboards, or customer-facing communications‚Äîall powered directly from your SAP CPQ or external system workflows.

entry.title: Re: FI_OT_DNC001 message
entry.content:
Dear @Andrea_Gr,

Message class FI_IT_DNC = ‚ÄûMessages for document numbering checks in Italy, I assume so‚Äù.

That means:

This error is part of the Italian document-numbering / ODN date-control logic.

On S/4HANA Cloud public edition, there are two different situations:

  1. If the other customer also has an Italian company code (country = IT)

Then you can get the same message there but only by activating the same Official Document Numbering (ODN) with date control.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4603118feda9495892abadbe8f8c3d14/b15cfc3e56404640af4458ff9a16eb38.html

There is no separate message control in Public Cloud, the only way to get FI_IT_DNC001 is to have the Italian ODN date-control active for that company code/doc type.

In this case the correct and supported way is to build your own check that behaves, for example:

Using the validation apps (no coding)

  1. Open Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Substitution/Validation Rules‚Äù
  2. Open an existing Validation rule or create a new one.
  3. In General Information:
    • Set Control Level = Error or Warning.
    • Click value help on the Message field.
  4. In the popup:
    • Message ID/number
    • Short text (what user will see)
    • Severity (error/warning)
    • Choose Create
    • Enter:
    • Save.
  5. Back in the rule, select this new message in Message.

Now this custom text will appear when the validation fails.

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4406')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e6175604fc874bfe84aa14d2f9ae1fbd/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/ac7785b7870344a8998c8492c0cd5c3d.html

Using a Badi:

  1. App Custom Logic find a Badi for FI document validation
  2. Implement logic, for example: FIN_ACDOC_HEADER_VALIDATION

 

    • Read posting date from the incoming document.
    • Compare with system date
    • If posting date > today and your other conditions are met raise an error message.

Summary:

  • FI_IT_DNC001 is Italian document-numbering date control not a generic message.
  • For non-Italian company codes, you cannot turn on FI_IT_DNC001 itself; instead, create a custom validation that blocks future posting dates and shows your own error text.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Workflow event trace ACTIVE but doesn't trace anything (transactions SWELS/SWEL)
entry.content:
I had a discussion with SAP Support about the design of SWELS screen. It's only possible to make SAP improve the screen by proposing an idea in the influence Web site.

But I can't find an "opportunity/campaign" where to suggest the idea... (the best one I could find is about SAP Build https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/2281) If anyone knows where to suggest, please tell me.

So, for those interested, I'm posting here an implicit enhancement at the beginning of the subroutine PBO_100 of the program RSWELSWITCH, which displays a message indicating the "actual activation" state.

If the date and time restrictions will make the trace virtually inactive in less than one hour, a message shows when the trace becomes inactive:

If the date and time restrictions make the trace virtually inactive now, a message clearly indicates the information:

Implicit enhancement at the beginning of the subroutine PBO_100 of the program RSWELSWITCH:

DATA:
  BEGIN OF zz,
    evtlog      TYPE swelcfg-evtlog,
    now         TYPE timestamp,
    swelcf      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF swelcf WITH EMPTY KEY,
    line_swelcf TYPE REF TO swelcf,
    s_date      TYPE RANGE OF d,
    s_time      TYPE RANGE OF t,
    s_tstp      TYPE RANGE OF timestampl,
    active_now  TYPE abap_bool,
    datlo       TYPE syst-datlo,
    timlo       TYPE syst-timlo,
    duration    TYPE i,
    timestamp   TYPE timestamp,
"""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""$"$\SE:(3) FORM PBO_100, D√©but, Extension ZZSRO_RSWELSWITCH, Stru. ZZ, Fin                                                                                   S
  END OF zz.
SELECT SINGLE EVTLOG FROM SWELCFG INTO @zz-evtlog.
IF    zz-evtlog      = 'X'
  AND g_limit_trace IS INITIAL.
  GET TIME STAMP FIELD zz-now.
  SELECT * FROM SWELCF INTO TABLE @zz-swelcf.
  LOOP AT zz-swelcf REFERENCE INTO zz-line_swelcf.
    CASE zz-line_swelcf->selfield.
      WHEN 'S_DATE'. " before note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_date.
      WHEN 'S_TIME'. " before note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_time.
      WHEN 'S_TSTP'. " since note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_tstp.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.

  zz-active_now = abap_false.
  IF zz-s_tstp IS NOT INITIAL.
    GET TIME STAMP FIELD zz-now.
    IF zz-now IN zz-s_tstp.
      zz-active_now = abap_true.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
    GET TIME.
    zz-datlo = sy-datlo.
    zz-timlo = sy-timlo.
    IF zz-datlo IN zz-s_date AND zz-timlo IN zz-s_time.
      zz-active_now = abap_true.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  IF zz-active_now = abap_true.
    zz-duration = 1.
    WHILE zz-duration <= 3600.
      IF zz-s_tstp IS NOT INITIAL.
        zz-timestamp = cl_abap_tstmp=>add( tstmp = zz-now
                                           secs  = zz-duration ).
        IF zz-timestamp NOT IN zz-s_tstp.
          g_limit_trace = 'X'.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE.
        zz-timlo = zz-timlo + 1.
        IF zz-timlo = '000000'.
          zz-datlo = zz-datlo + 1.
        ENDIF.
        IF NOT ( zz-datlo IN zz-s_date AND zz-timlo IN zz-s_time ).
          g_limit_trace = 'X'.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
      zz-duration = zz-duration + 1.
    ENDWHILE.

    IF g_limit_trace = 'X'.
      g_limit_trace = |Trace deactivated in { CONV t( zz-duration ) TIME = USER } hours|.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
    g_limit_trace = 'Trace in fact INACTIVE due to date/time restrictions'.
  ENDIF.
ENDIF.

Note that the code considers the situation of RSWELSWITCH working with or without the note 3461138 - SWEL: Event doesn't appear in Event Trace - SAP for Me. Before the fix, the date and time restrictions are stored according to the user's local time zone (lines S_DATE and S_TIME in the table SWELCF), and after the fix they are stored according to the UTC time zone (S_TSTP).

entry.title: Re: S/4 Hana public cloud - Key User - Create Custom Tile...
entry.content:
Dear @LEOIER,

With only the Custom Tiles app and a Custom Data Browser you cannot make one dynamic tile that automatically adapts across DEV / TEST / PROD in Public Cloud.

The correct key-user way to expose a custom CDS view as a tile is to treat it as embedded analytics and publish it via Custom Analytical Queries, not via a URL tile.

Recommended approach (key-user, cloud-friendly)

Assuming your CDS is for reporting / display of data the clean way in Public Cloud is:

  1. Open Custom CDS Views.
  2. Create a new view (YY1_‚Ä¶):
    • Set Scenario = Analytical Cube/Dimension

 

    • Choose the primary data source (I_* view or your existing custom CDS)
  1. Add associations, elements, and calculated fields as needed.
  2. Publish the CDS.

Use Custom Analytical Queries app

  1. Open Custom Analytical Queries.
  2. Create New:
    • Query Name: YY1_YOURNAME
    • Data Source: your analytical cube CDS
  3. In tabs:
    • Field Selection ‚Äì choose dimensions/measures.
    • Display ‚Äì put fields on rows/columns, configure measures.
    • Filters ‚Äì set fixed filters and user input filters.
  4. Save then Publish the query.

Now you have a proper analytical query object that is already ‚Äûtile-ready‚Äù

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/33f3a229ecfe438ca6b2053c48b4e1bb.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-cloud-embedded-analytics-custom-analytical-queries/ba-p/13738288

Publish the query as a tile

From the Custom Analytical Queries:

  • Open your query and hit Preview.
  • In the preview view, use the Share menu:
    • Option 1: Save as Tile (personal) ‚Äì good for your own testing.

 

    • Option 2 (recommended for others): In many latest setups you use Manage KPIs and Reports / Custom Analytical Queries and Services to formally publish the query and create a tile linked to a business catalog.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/4ef099d254cd4f8a96df001496f53952.html

Put the tile into a business catalog (Custom Catalog Extensions)

Use Custom Catalog Extensions

  1. Open Custom Catalog Extensions.
  2. Choose or create a customer business catalog where you want the tile.
  3. Add your newly created analytical app / tile to that catalog.
  4. Make sure that catalog is assigned to a business role

Users with that role will now see your tile on their Launchpad.

More details below:

https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-custom-ui-generate-tile..html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/how-to-check-business-catalog-to-be-assigned-for-custom-in-app-application/qaq-p/13682231

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-embedded-analytics-user-roles/ba-p/13518142

Transport to TEST / PROD (dynamic across systems)

Because you‚Äôre using only in-app key user objects:

  • Custom CDS View
  • Custom Analytical Queries
  • Tile / Catalog Extension

You can move them by Export Software Collection app from. That‚Äôs what makes it effectively dynamic per system in S/4HANA Cloud.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/6896de5f70c54753ac028f444eafa16f.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Investment Boost: A significant step to promote economic growth
entry.content:
Hi Bino,

Many thanks for this info. I have followed the set-up for straight line and the have an issue with the resultant ordinary depreciation for subsequent acquisitions in that the depreciation is calculating on the depreciation start date of the original acquisition i.e. all acquisitions in the year will depreciate for the full year. In our case we want ordinary depreciation to be calculated based on the asset value date of the subsequent acquisitions.

I then changed the period control for the ordinary depreciation phase 1 to a key that has the ‚Äòcalculate depreciation from the asset value date‚Äô indicator set.  That though then results in the special depreciation doubling up.

Could you please advise on how to overcome this?

Many thanks

entry.title: Re: Investment Boost: A significant step to promote economic growth
entry.content:
Hi Bino, 

What I omitted previously is that we depreciate based on stated percentages rather than useful life.

Cheers

entry.title: Customer Confirmation on Proof of Delivery
entry.content:
Hi All

The SAP provided proof of delivery processing allows you to record what the customer has indicated as the actual receipt of goods so that the customer can only be invoiced based on the PoD processed for the customer.

However, there seems to be no functionality / text available where a customer's confirmation number / verification number can be stored in the underlying delivery document when the POD is processed. That could lead to conflicts as there is no place to have a customer confirmation number be captured in the delivery when the POD is processed.

How do we capture the customer's POD reference and Date on the POD transaction ?

Appreciate your help

Regards

Rohit Zalani

entry.title: Introducing LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect with SAP SuccessFactors: Integrated Hiring Made Easy
entry.content:
We‚Äôre thrilled to announce the launch of Recruiter System Connect (RSC) with SAP Success Factors, a powerful integration designed to transform how talent acquisition teams work. This collaboration brings together the power of LinkedIn Recruiter and SAP‚Äôs enterprise-grade applicant tracking capabilities, creating a seamless experience for recruiters and hiring managers.

Why This Matters

Recruiting today is complex. Teams often juggle multiple systems, leading to inefficiencies, duplicated efforts, and inconsistent candidate data. RSC solves these challenges by connecting LinkedIn Recruiter directly with your SAP SuccessFactors ATS, enabling real-time data synchronization and streamlined workflows.

Key Benefits for Joint Customers

  • Unified Candidate Data: Access consistent, up-to-date candidate information across LinkedIn Recruiter and SAP. No more toggling between platforms or dealing with outdated records.
  • Faster, Smarter Hiring Decisions: With bi-directional syncing, recruiters can see applicant history, interview feedback, and hiring outcomes directly in LinkedIn Recruiter. This means better-informed outreach and reduced risk of duplicate engagement.
  • Improved Candidate Experience: By eliminating redundant steps and ensuring recruiters have full context, candidates enjoy a smoother, more personalized journey.
  • Time Savings and Efficiency: Customers using RSC report saving up to 3.5 hours per recruiter per week by reducing manual data entry and platform switching.
  • Free to Activate: Like all LinkedIn integrations, RSC is free to activate‚Äîdelivering immediate ROI without additional cost.

Learn about all of the 2H 2025 Release Highlights for SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting.

Unable to customise categories (Doesn‚Äôt meet accessibility standards)

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - November 2025
entry.content:
Contents

Summary. 1

Raindrop. 1

Zip State of spend. 2

S&P Outlook. 2

AQPC. 3

McKinsey. 3

Icertis. 3

 

Summary

Across these reports, three trends stand out:

  • Flexible, agile procurement operating models are the new competitive differentiator.
  • AI and analytics drive efficiency and resilience but require deliberate strategy, skills investment, and integration.
  • Contract and supply chain complexity demand advanced intelligence platforms and process automation.

Procurement leaders should prioritize business-aligned technology adoption, scenario-based planning, and cross-functional talent development. Process and organizational design must emphasize agility and strategic value, deploying orchestration and AI tools wherever possible. Agility and digital mastery will define the winners

Raindrop

An interesting report that discusses how Procurement and finance leaders face a major gap between their ambitions around agility and AI innovation, and their ability to deliver real change. Raindrop‚Äôs survey of 1,000 U.S. decision-makers shows 73 percent prioritize flexibility, yet only 27 percent feel empowered to innovate, and a staggering 18 percent have not adopted any AI in procurement. Legacy cost-focused mindsets, slow institutional buy-in, outdated technology, and skills shortages block progress. The COVID pandemic and subsequent shocks (Ukraine, Panama Canal, shipping crises) forced abrupt changes. Many teams found themselves unprepared‚Äî40 percent endured severe delays, and years spent prioritizing cost savings over digital capability left organizations exposed.

AI adoption is limited but promising. Only 15 percent have embraced advanced tools, yet over 80 percent see themselves responsible for innovation. Barriers include culture, investment, and skills gaps, not system readiness alone. The report insists that flexibility in procurement is no longer optional. It must be linked to strategic business outcomes, not just cost or risk metrics. AI‚Äôs best opportunities‚Äîin data analysis, automation, collaboration, and risk management‚Äîfree talent for strategic work. Leaders should measure procurement not only by savings but alignment with growth, supplier relationships, and business enablement. The future will favour those who move rapidly to adopt AI, change executive perceptions, and partner with proven technology providers to close readiness gaps. Practical next steps: invest in AI-native platforms, upgrade talent, and restructure incentives around flexibility and strategic impact. Flexibility, combined with AI, is now the critical foundation for future-proof procurement.

Zip State of spend

Zip‚Äôs global survey of 1,030 procurement and finance leaders reveals that AI already shapes how businesses plan, hire, and spend. 67 % use AI in spend and supplier management, with 17 % deploying it widely. The shift is broad: processes are moving digital, tech stacks are fragmenting, and spend priorities shift from goods to people-based services, especially professional services, consultancy, and contingent labour. Nearly three-quarters now factor AI capability into hiring decisions, and IT headcount is projected to rise, while procurement teams remain flat or shrink in large organizations.

Despite strong optimism around AI, execution lags. Most leaders feel somewhat prepared but lack defined strategies, skills, and operational governance. The top skills for future procurement are AI fluency, data analytics, and supplier collaboration. Smaller companies embrace best-of-breed and orchestration approaches; large enterprises consolidate and await incumbent vendor innovation. Leaders cite inflexible processes as the single biggest barrier to procurement‚Äôs influence; modernization and automation are urgent.

Spend control and tech strategy must reflect this landscape. Procurement leaders should prioritize data architecture for orchestration, embrace hybrid tech stacks, and focus savings on people-related services. The next three years require deliberate investment in talent, process redesign, and adoption of orchestration technologies. AI will reshape operating models, but success depends on business alignment and technology readiness

S&P Outlook

According to S&P‚Äôs latest report the Q4 2025 supply chain outlook is dominated by uncertainty: tariffs, trade reviews, and sector-specific duty changes disrupt global flows. U.S. duties remain in flux‚Äîfrom emergency (IEEPA) programs to Section 232 and 301 reviews impacting electronics, medical supplies, and aerospace. Trade activity is slowing; October saw a 0.4 percent drop year-over-year, with weak growth forecasts (1.7 percent for 2026). Container shipping volumes contract sharply, affecting supply chain costs and timelines. Corporate profits globally have taken a $900 billion hit from supply disruptions and tariffs since January. Firms pass higher costs to consumers selectively, negotiate with suppliers for cost sharing, and delay long-term investments in favour of tactical responses.

Regulatory complexity in the U.S., EU, and Asia persists, with ongoing legal cases and shifting exemptions constantly redrawing the risk map. Climate, cyber, and conflict risks add further stress. The report highlights sustained tactical decision-making, with little strategic investment until more policy clarity arrives. Vertically integrated firms have more resilience, but weak supply chains see margin expectations fall by up to 140 basis points. Procurement leaders should focus on cost modelling, flexible sourcing, and contract renegotiation to weather the ongoing uncertainty. Develop deeper supplier relationships, optimize for agility, and watch labour cost structures when considering reshoring options

AQPC

This reports covers the top use cases and benefits of AI adoption in procurement which according to their research remains limited.

58% of surveyed organizations have yet to implement it, but those that have report substantial results. The top three use cases: spend analysis (78%), sourcing insights, and pricing intelligence. AI tools automate spend classification, detect anomalies, and forecast spend. They support supplier discovery, scenario modelling, and help manage price fluctuations, renegotiation, and total cost of ownership evaluations. Benefits include improved data quality (80 % see gains), stronger decision making, increased savings, scaled expertise, and reduced contract leakage.

AI enables higher data accuracy, proactive risk management, and process automation. It lets procurement functions standardize contracts, analyse risky terms, and respond faster to business changes. For SAP and engineering leaders, invest in data integration, model governance, and real-time analytics. Procurement teams should experiment with guided onboarding, contract risk analysis, and predictive tools. The report urges firms to address privacy and ethics, manage verification, and prepare robust governance to maximize AI benefits

McKinsey

This article which takes data from several surveys, suggests that Procurement functions face a ‚Äúperfect storm‚Äù combining macro volatility and digital disruption. Managed spend per FTE is up 50% over five years; expectations and complexity have grown. AI agents promise radical gains‚Äîpotentially driving 25‚Äì40 % efficiency improvements by shifting non-strategic work to automation. Leading firms create hybrid workforces where procurement professionals partner with digital agents, freeing time for strategy.

Organizational maturity correlates with profitability. Strategic category management, dedicated centres of excellence, and advanced analytics drive tangible value (five percentage points or more in EBITDA margin for leaders). Examples include firms saving 10‚Äì20% on costs after redesigning category and sourcing models, deploying AI for invoice reconciliation, and leveraging COEs for process excellence.

Attendees at McKinsey‚Äôs CPO Forum cite stress, talent, and digital enablement as top priorities. Many still underuse procure-to-pay, SRM, and e-sourcing tools. The best advice: separate strategic and transactional roles, build out COEs, invest in AI and data analytics, and elevate procurement to a central, business-driving function. Process automation is the bedrock of the reimagined procurement organization

Icertis

According to this viewpoint from Icertis, Rising tariff complexity forces procurement teams to rethink contract management and sourcing strategies. The report argues that contract intelligence is critical for navigating cost increases, compliance, and supply disruptions brought by rapidly changing trade policies. CFOs now cite tariffs as their top concern, up 270 % this year. Practical responses include pull-forward sourcing, stockpiling, shifting production, and contract renegotiation.

Their key advice: audit contracts to identify price adjustment, termination, and hardship clauses. Incoterms, fixed-price, and price adjustment clauses determine who bears tariff costs and ability to renegotiate. Organizations need centralized and AI-enabled contract intelligence to surface critical terms quickly. The average large enterprise has contract data in 24 systems, leading to poor visibility and missed opportunities‚Äîup to 70% of contract value is lost to obligations not tracked.

Icertis showcases AI-driven workflows for renegotiation, onboarding new suppliers, and compliance management. SAP leaders should integrate contract intelligence platforms to automate workflows and harmonize terms with ERP systems. The agile use of contract insights ensures rapid, strategic responses to new tariffs and mitigates risk

 

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: SAP Focused Run: Trigger custom actions on work modes in IT Calendar & Work Mode Management
entry.content:
A work mode represents a specific operational state or event of a system, for instance, when it is taken offline for maintenance or is temporarily unavailable. These modes help both users and administrators stay informed about the current status of their systems. 

You can create and manage work modes using the IT Calendar and & Work Mode Management application in SAP Focused Run. One of the key work mode types is Planned Downtime, which is used when a system is deliberately taken offline for maintenance or updates. During a planned downtime, alerts for the affected system are automatically suppressed, helping to avoid unnecessary notifications while maintenance is in progress.

With SAP Focused Run 5.2, you can now trigger your own custom actions as follow-ups to planned maintenance events. For example, SAP Focused Run includes the Operations Automation application, which provides system health check guided procedures to help assess the health of managed systems. A guided procedure consists of predefined steps and activities that guide you through the health check process. You can either use a SAP-delivered health check guided procedure or create a custom one tailored to your specific requirements.

Let us now see how we can‚ÄØrun one of these guided procedures before, during, or after a maintenance event, making it easier to automate health checks and streamline your maintenance processes. 

First stage: Backend Configuration

Background job SAP_FRN_WMM_EXT_TRIGGER_ACTION runs every five minutes and identifies work modes that meet any of the following criteria: 

  1. Work modes that started or ended in the last 5 minutes 
  2. Ongoing work modes 
  3. Work mode that will start or end in the next 5 minutes 

All the work modes identified by the background job are then passed to the BAdI: BADI_TRIGGER_ACTION_ON_WMM for further processing. This BAdI provides different methods that are called based on the timing of the work mode in relation to the current time. The methods are defined as follows: 

  1. PROCESS_WMM_PRE_RUN - This method receives all work modes with start time or end time within the last five minutes (i.e., five minutes before the current time).
  2. PROCESS_ONGOING_WMM   - This method receives all ongoing work modes. That is all work modes that are currently active. 
  3. PROCESS_WMM_POST_RUN - This method handles work modes where the start time or end time falls within the next five minutes (i.e., five minutes after the current time). 

According to the use case, the customer can implement the methods listed above.As explained before, we can explore the use case to trigger a guided procedure which will perform the system health check for the managed system on which maintenance event is planned.‚ÄØ

Let us look at an example where we trigger a guided procedure using this BAdI 

  1. Create a Z BAdI implementation for BAdI: BADI_TRIGGER_ACTION_ON_WMM .
  2. We want to trigger the guided procedure execution within 5 minutes of the maintenance event completion. So, for this implement method‚ÄØPROCESS_WMM_POST_RUN with below sample code. 

Sample code snippet

METHOD if_trigger_action_on_wmm~process_wmm_post_run.

DATA: ls_object TYPE sdiagls_base_landscape,
           ls_log TYPE itcal_s_trigger_wmm_logs,
          lr_landscape_obj TYPE REF TO cl_diagls_base_landscape,
         lr_technical_system TYPE REF TO cl_diagls_technical_system,
        lv_jname TYPE tbtcjob-jobname,
       lv_inst_number TYPE diag_global_id,
      lr_database TYPE REF TO cl_diagls_database,
     lt_messages TYPE bapiret2_t.

FIELD-SYMBOLS <fs_struc> TYPE any.

TRY.

LOOP AT it_wm_details ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_wm_details>) .
IF <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid EQ <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_parent_guid. "Restricting technical components


"Fetch system details using lmdb guid.

DATA(lv_lmdb_guid36) = cl_lmdb_guid_util=>convert_guid_c32_to_c36( guid = <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid ).

DATA(lr_base_obj) = cl_gpa_exec_util=>get_ts_by_guid(
im_lmdb_guid36 = '' && lv_lmdb_guid36 )-base_landscape.
ls_object = cl_gpa_exec_util=>get_ts_by_guid(
im_lmdb_guid36 = '' && lv_lmdb_guid36 ).


*Database managed system

IF cl_diagls_util=>is_database( im_base_landscape = lr_base_obj ).
lr_database ?= lr_base_obj.
DATA(lv_id) = lr_database->get_id( ).
DATA(lv_typ) = lr_database->get_type( ).

CALL FUNCTION 'FM_EXTRN_GP_EXEC'
EXPORTING
iv_gp_id = '' "Provide GP id(required field)
iv_rep_type = 'HTML'
iv_system_id = lv_id
iv_system_type = lv_typ
iv_mailtpl = '' "Provide a mail template(required field)
run_background = abap_true
* iv_recipient_list = ''
IMPORTING
ev_jobname = lv_jname
ev_instance_number = lv_inst_number
et_messages = lt_messages.

ls_log-wm_id = <fs_wm_details>-wmm_id.
ls_log-log_text = |Guided procedure scheduled in background. Job name is { lv_jname }|.
ls_log-context_guid = <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid.
GET TIME STAMP FIELD ls_log-timestamp.
APPEND ls_log TO it_logs.

*Technical system


ELSEIF cl_diagls_util=>is_technical_system( im_base_landscape = lr_base_obj ).

lr_base_obj->get_structure_as_data(
RECEIVING
re_structure = DATA(lr_struc_data) " Common data shared amongt all Landscape entities.
).
ASSIGN lr_struc_data->* TO <fs_struc>.
IF sy-subrc = 0.

DATA lv_sid TYPE char255.
DATA lv_type TYPE char255.

ASSIGN COMPONENT 'SID' OF STRUCTURE <fs_struc> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_sid>).
IF sy-subrc = 0.
lv_sid = <lv_sid>.
ENDIF.

ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TYPE' OF STRUCTURE <fs_struc> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_type>).
IF sy-subrc = 0.
lv_type = <lv_type>.
ENDIF.
ENDIF.
CALL FUNCTION 'FM_EXTRN_GP_EXEC'
EXPORTING
iv_gp_id = '' "Provide GP id(required field)
iv_rep_type = 'HTML'
iv_system_id = lv_sid
iv_system_type = lv_type
iv_mailtpl = '' "Provide a mail template(required field)
run_background = abap_true
* iv_recipient_list = ''
IMPORTING
ev_jobname = lv_jname
ev_instance_number = lv_inst_number
et_messages = lt_messages.
ls_log-wm_id = <fs_wm_details>-wmm_id.
ls_log-log_text = |Guided procedure scheduled in background. Job name is { lv_jname }|.
ls_log-context_guid = <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid.
GET TIME STAMP FIELD ls_log-timestamp.
APPEND ls_log TO it_logs.


*Host

ELSEIF cl_diagls_util=>is_host( im_base_landscape = lr_base_obj ).
lv_sid = lr_base_obj->get_id( ).
CALL FUNCTION 'FM_EXTRN_GP_EXEC'
EXPORTING
iv_gp_id = '' "Provide GP id(required field)
iv_rep_type = 'HTML'
iv_system_id = lv_sid
iv_mailtpl = '' "Provide a mail template(required field)
run_background = abap_true
iv_host = 'X'
* iv_recipient_list = ''
IMPORTING
ev_jobname = lv_jname
ev_instance_number = lv_inst_number
et_messages = lt_messages.
ls_log-wm_id = <fs_wm_details>-wmm_id.
ls_log-log_text = |Guided procedure scheduled in background. Job name is { lv_jname }|.
ls_log-context_guid = <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid.
GET TIME STAMP FIELD ls_log-timestamp.
APPEND ls_log TO it_logs.


*External service


ELSEIF cl_diagls_util=>is_external_service( im_base_landscape = lr_base_obj ).

lr_base_obj->get_structure_as_data(
RECEIVING
re_structure = lr_struc_data " Common data shared amongt all Landscape entities.
).
ASSIGN lr_struc_data->* TO <fs_struc>.
ASSIGN COMPONENT 'LONG_SID' OF STRUCTURE <fs_struc> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_long_sid>).
IF sy-subrc = 0.
lv_sid = <lv_long_sid>.
ENDIF.

ASSIGN COMPONENT 'APPLICATION_DOMAIN' OF STRUCTURE <fs_struc> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_app_domain>).
IF sy-subrc = 0.
lv_type = <lv_app_domain>.
ENDIF.
CALL FUNCTION 'FM_EXTRN_GP_EXEC'
EXPORTING
iv_gp_id = '' "Provide GP id(required field)
iv_rep_type = 'HTML'
iv_system_id = lv_sid
iv_system_type = lv_type
iv_mailtpl = '' "Provide a mail template(required field)
run_background = abap_true
* iv_recipient_list = ''
IMPORTING
ev_jobname = lv_jname
ev_instance_number = lv_inst_number
et_messages = lt_messages.
ls_log-wm_id = <fs_wm_details>-wmm_id.
ls_log-log_text = |Guided procedure scheduled in background. Job name is { lv_jname }|.
ls_log-context_guid = <fs_wm_details>-lmdb_guid.
GET TIME STAMP FIELD ls_log-timestamp.
APPEND ls_log TO it_logs.
ENDIF.
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.
CATCH cx_sise_exception.
ENDTRY.
ENDMETHOD.

Second stage:Plan a maintenance event

  • In the IT Calendar & Work Mode Management application, create a work mode for any managed system.

      

As per our BAdI implementation, within 5 minutes of the work mode's completion guided procedure should be triggered.

  • Once the work mode is finished, choose Action Logs on the event in the IT calendar to see the logs we have provided in   the BAdI implementation.

All logs generated as part of your implementation will be available here. For our sample use case, you can include details such as the guided procedure ID, name, guided procedure runtime status etc. 

  • You can also verify the guided procedure execution in the Operations Automation app.  Choose System management as the application area to verify health check guided procedure instance that was triggered from the work mode.

Conclusion

By using event-based actions in IT Calendar & Work Mode Management, we can ensure that important maintenance activities are automatically handled at the right time. The background job and BAdI together support custom logic and system-specific actions. This approach enhances operational efficiency and helps administrators maintain better visibility and control during maintenance cycles.

entry.title: Change of Technical Administrator (Americas Region)
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team

We kindly request to update the Technical Administrator for the Order Form (Case ID) listed below.
*We confirmed with our account manager that the request should be submitted under the component: XX-SER-SAPSMP-USR. However, since we are unable to locate it, we kindly ask you to forward this internally within SAP.
 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Change of Technical Administrator (Americas Region)
entry.content:
Firstly, I have to inform you that the XX-SER-SAPSMP-USR provided by Account Manager has already been sunset, so you cannot select this component to report a case. Additionally, SAP for Me support generally issues related to S-users and S-user roles. Regarding the change of the technical administrator for your order, I tried to find the following information for your reference:

1. According to your description "update the Technical Administrator for the Order Form ", not sure if you mean update the Purchase Order and/or Maintenance Responsible Contacts.

If in that case, the KBA 3597947 - How to create and manage Purchase Order and/or Maintenance Responsible Contacts using 'Your Finance Contacts' card - SAP for Me is relevant. Attached the screenshot for your reference.

2. If it's not the situation mentioned above, then I think SAP for Me probably does not support this feature. I found an internal KBA 3423106 - How to change billing contact person - SAP for Me [INTERNAL ONLY] in the backend system, but since it is internal, customers cannot review it. I have abstracted the content for your reference. You may contact your Account Manager to see if they can help you create an IT ticket to resolve this issue. Your Account Manager can view this internal KBA thus please also provide it to him.

Resolution

Contact the Account Manager and provide below necessary information:

  • ERP number
  • Sales organization/company code (for example 0001 for SAP SE, 0015 for SAP Asia etc.)
  • Requested e-mail address
  • Does this relate to all LOBs or only specific LOB/billing type?

Then the Account Manager should create an IT Ticket (Type : O2I Digital Invoice Delivery ) to change the billing contact person.

For Ariba, please refer to document: https://one.int.sap/functional_areas/finance/order_to_invoice/digital_invoice_delivery.

entry.title: Why SAP Introduced Fiori Spaces & Pages
entry.content:
SAP Fiori Spaces and Pages are the modern way of structuring the SAP Launchpad in S/4HANA.
They define how users see their apps, how navigation is organized, and how roles are delivered in a clean, controlled, and role-based layout.

Spaces & Pages replace the old Groups concept with a much more powerful and user-friendly approach.

The Problem with Old ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù

Fiori Groups were simple, but they created massive operational and UX challenges in S/4HANA environments:

Inconsistent Across Users

Users could hide/reorder tiles ‚Üí no standard layout.
Impossible to enforce governance.

Overloaded Launchpads

Many users had 80‚Äì120 tiles, making it slow and hard to use.

Not Role-Based

Groups didn‚Äôt represent business roles or personas (CFO, Controller, AP, AR, Treasury Manager).

Poor Navigation

Scrolling through endless tiles led to productivity loss.

Not Future-Proof

Groups do not support SAP‚Äôs modern UX roadmap (OVP, UI5 innovations, predictive analytics).

Result:
Low adoption, poor user satisfaction, and high training/support efforts.

 

How Fiori Spaces & Pages Solve These Problems

Spaces & Pages are SAP‚Äôs modern approach to delivering a role-based, consistent, scalable, and intuitive launchpad.

True Role-Based UX (Persona-Centric)

Each role gets a dedicated Space:

  • CFO Space
  • Controller Space
  • AP Space
  • AR Space
  • Treasury Space

Every user sees the same consistent layout, reducing:

  • confusion
  • training effort
  • troubleshooting
  • audit issues

Clean, Structured, Multi-Level Navigation

Spaces ‚Üí Pages ‚Üí Sections ‚Üí Tiles

This hierarchy aligns perfectly with end-to-end finance processes.

Example for CFO:

  • Space: CFO Insights
    • Page 1: Finance Insights
    • Page 2: Corporate Finance
    • Page 3: Treasury & Cash
    • Page 4: AP/AR Operations

Enterprise Governance

Spaces restrict user personalization.

Users cannot delete, move, or add tiles, preventing:

  • clutter
  • incorrect layouts
  • unauthorized tile usage
  • configuration mistakes

Perfect for SOX, audit, and compliance-driven organizations.

Faster Navigation and Better Performance

Pages load faster, are logically grouped, and allow CFOs to find critical insights in seconds ‚Äî not minutes.

Standardization Across the Organization

Every user with the same role sees the same design:
Perfect for:

  • global teams
  • multi-country deployments
  • shared service centers
  • integration with training & SOPs

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Re: Analyze Production Cost ‚Äì Event-based
entry.content:
Please check help for the field From Fiscal Period.

It shows:

Fiscal Period From / To

The current fiscal period is shown by default, and you can adjust the date range as required.

Only postings within the specified time frame are considered.

If an order has no postings in the date range you specify, it will appear in the table with zeros for each value.

Note that this is different to the Event-Based Work in Process app, where orders without postings are not shown.

 

------------------------------------------------------

In another word, the restriction is on postings, not on the closed date.

entry.title: Re: Configuration currently locked in "Manage G/L Account...
entry.content:
Please refer to the following advice for your issue

Symptom

  • Error message: "Changes not possible. Configuration locked" displayed in the Manage G/L Account Master Data app [1]
  • G/L account modifications blocked in Development system (DEV)
  • System preventing any changes to chart of accounts configuration

Current Situation Analysis

  • Locked System: Development environment experiencing configuration lock
  • Pending Transport: Chart of accounts transport request currently in Quality environment
  • Business Impact: Critical - unable to make necessary G/L account changes for business operations

Root Cause Investigation

The configuration lock typically occurs due to several possible scenarios:

  1. System Upgrade Phase: During system upgrades, changes are temporarily blocked to prevent conflicts [2]
  2. Transport Dependencies: Conflicting transport requests between development and quality systems
  3. User Lock Conflicts: Another user may have an open draft or be editing the same accounts [3]

Resolution Options

Option 1: Check for Open Drafts in Successor App
  1. Access the 'Manage Operating G/L Accounts' application
  2. Click on Edit to access any existing drafts
  3. Discard the existing draft to release the lock [3]
  4. Return to 'Manage G/L Account Master Data' app to make changes
Option 2: BCP Project Management (If During Upgrade Phase)
  1. Create a new BCP (Business Configuration Project) in the development system [2]
  2. Assign your user to the BCP project before making changes
  3. Ensure the BCP project is open and active for G/L account modifications
  4. Use the Synchronize App if urgent changes need to reach production during upgrade phase [2]
Option 3: Transport Coordination Approach
  1. Coordinate with the transport owner in Quality environment
  2. Import the pending chart of accounts transport back to Development
  3. Merge configuration changes in Development system
  4. Create a new consolidated transport request
  5. Move the updated transport through the system landscape

Step-by-Step Resolution

  1. Immediate Check: Verify if you're in a system upgrade phase by checking system status
  2. Draft Verification: Access 'Manage Operating G/L Accounts' app to check for open drafts [3]
  3. User Assignment: Ensure your user is assigned to an active BCP project if in upgrade phase [2]
  4. Transport Analysis: Review the relationship between DEV changes and QAS transport
  5. Execute Resolution: Apply the most appropriate resolution option based on findings
  6. Validate Changes: Confirm G/L account modifications can be made successfully

Validation Checklist

  • Configuration lock successfully released
  • G/L account changes applied without errors
  • Transport request created or updated appropriately
  • No system inconsistencies detected
  • Quality environment transport status verified

Preventive Measures

  • Establish clear transport coordination procedures between development and quality teams
  • Create BCP projects before system upgrade phases begin [2]
  • Assign users to BCP projects proactively during upgrade periods
  • Implement regular checks for open drafts in G/L account management apps
  • Maintain documentation of active transport requests across system landscape

Key Considerations

In a standard three-tier SAP S/4HANA system landscape, all G/L account configurations should be performed in the Development system and transported systematically to Test/Quality and Production systems [1]. The Quality and Production systems typically have read-only access to prevent unauthorized changes.


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better

Br.Bob

entry.title: Smarter Skills-Based Hiring with SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
SAP Fieldglass makes skills-based hiring faster and more accurate. With flexible placement of qualifications, AI-suggested skills, a unified qualifications library, standardized 1‚Äì5 rating scales, and smarter candidate matching based on qualifications‚Äînot just job codes‚Äî buyers and suppliers get clearer insights and better-aligned candidates with less manual effort.

These enhancements help organizations find the right talent quickly and consistently.

1. Enable Skills-Based Hiring Where It Matters Most 

Hiring needs differ across contingent types and roles. SAP Fieldglass lets you decide exactly where to apply skills-based hiring‚Äîat either the contingent type level or on job posting templates. 

This flexibility means the Qualifications section appears where you need it most, ensuring skill requirements are visible and consistent without disrupting existing postings. Buyers can communicate expectations clearly, while suppliers instantly understand what‚Äôs required. 

 
Use Case 

A professional services firm hiring temporary consultants enabled Skills-Based Hiring on its job posting templates. This enhancement allows hiring managers to review job descriptions and add relevant skills directly within the posting‚Äîwithout navigating across multiple pages. As a result, they can complete job postings more quickly, reducing back-and-forth navigation and saving valuable time. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2.  Get Smarter with AI-Powered Qualification Recommendations 

Buyers often spend time reviewing old postings trying to remember which skills to include‚Äîor forget key qualifications altogether. 

With AI-powered qualification recommendations, SAP Fieldglass uses machine learning to analyze your job title and description. It then suggests relevant skills. Buyers can easily add them to postings, ensuring consistency and completeness. Suppliers, in turn, align workforce records to these skills, improving match quality. 

 Use Case: 
A healthcare provider hiring temporary nurses across multiple locations used AI recommendations to surface essential skills like ICU experience and EMR familiarity. By including these automatically suggested qualifications, they received better-aligned candidates and reduced supplier clarifications. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. Bring Consistency with the Unified Qualification Library 

Ever noticed how ‚ÄúAzure Cloud,‚Äù ‚ÄúAzure‚Äù, and ‚ÄúMS Azure‚Äù all describe the same skill? When buyers use varied terminology, comparing candidates‚Äô terminology and the buyer‚Äôs terminology becomes a nightmare for the suppliers. 

The SAP Fieldglass Unified Qualification Library solves this by consolidating all qualification data into a Unified Qualification Library. Suppliers can merge duplicate skills, retain assessment ratings, and permanently align workforce data with buyer requirements. 

This consistency reduces errors, accelerates submissions, and ensures that skills mean the same thing across the board. 

 Use Case: 
A global IT services firm once had to manually reconcile skill names across five suppliers. With the unified library, ‚ÄúJava Developer‚Äù and ‚ÄúJ2EE Developer‚Äù are automatically consolidated, and machine learning flags exact matches to the buyer‚Äôs terminology of their requirements. The result? Less admin work and faster, more accurate candidate evaluations. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

4. Assessment Scale Normalization 

Different buyers often use different rating scales for the same skill‚Äîone might rate Excel proficiency 1‚Äì3, another 1‚Äì5. That inconsistency makes fair comparisons difficult. 

SAP Fieldglass now normalizes assessment scales across postings and workforce records. All SAP Fieldglass Unified Qualification scales are standardized to a 1‚Äì5 scale, with updates synchronized in real time. 

Use Case: 
An engineering firm hiring external project managers saw varied skill ratings across buyers. Normalization of the SAP Fieldglass Unified Qualifications on candidate's workforce record to a common 1-5 scale ensures every candidate was evaluated accurately and and that evaluations are easy to maintain. 

An Important aspect of this feature is that the workforce record always uses a standardized 1‚Äì5 scale. If a buyer uses a different rating scale‚Äîfor example, 1‚Äì10‚Äîthe system automatically converts the workforce rating to match. So, if a worker‚Äôs Java skill is rated 5 on the 1‚Äì5 scale, it will display as 10 on the buyer‚Äôs 1‚Äì10 scale. 

5. Skill-based Matching of  Potential Candidates 

Previously, SAP Fieldglass matched potential candidates only by job code, which sometimes meant great talent slipped through the cracks because the system overlooked highly qualified candidates whose job codes didn‚Äôt exactly match. 

Now, potential candidates are identified based on either job code or matching qualifications. The enhanced modal appears directly in the Qualifications section and displays match percentages for quick evaluation. Only candidates with at least a 25% qualification match are shown‚Äîhelping buyers or hiring managers focus on the most relevant profiles. 

Use Case: 

 A company hiring logistics coordinators during peak season found candidates who didn‚Äôt share the same job code but matched key qualifications. The system flagged one with a 70% match, helping recruiters fill roles faster. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Quick Tips and Things to Know 

  • The Enable Skills-Based Hiring flag must first be unhidden and unlocked at the contingent type level before it appears on job posting templates. 
  • Updating the Enable Skills-Based Hiring flag doesn‚Äôt affect existing postings‚Äîonly new ones inherit the change. 
  • Ensure workforce records are updated before relying on AI recommendations for accurate results. 
  • Consent is required before viewing recommended qualifications. 
  • Potential Candidates are displayed only if their match rate is 25% or higher. 

Skills-based hiring isn‚Äôt just about finding candidates‚Äîit‚Äôs about finding the right candidates, faster. With these enhancements, SAP Fieldglass empowers organizations to standardize skill data, streamline job postings, and make data-driven hiring decisions with confidence.  

Have you tried skills-based hiring in SAP Fieldglass? Share your experiences in the comments, and don‚Äôt forget to check the documentation on the SAP Fieldglass Help Portal for more insights. 

You can also have a look at the following topics in the What‚Äôs New Viewer for SAP Fieldglass for more details: 

  • Enable Skills-Based Hiring Flag Enhancements 
  • Skills-Based Matching of Potential Candidates 
  • SAP Fieldglass Unified Qualification Library Enhancements

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: SAP Public Cloud, agilidade e ganhos com ERP em Nuvem
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025 nos regal√≥ una charla esclarecedora de @Jean_Chess_IT Jean Tiago Baena, Director de Chess SAP Services y consultor SAP MM con m√°s de 18 a√±os de experiencia en implementaciones SAP ECC y S/4 HANA con actuaci√≥n en proyectos globales. Jean, quien comenz√≥ como frentista en un puesto de gasolina y hoy dirige su propia consultor√≠a SAP en Londrina, nos gui√≥ a trav√©s de un fascinante viaje sobre c√≥mo SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud est√° transformando la manera en que las empresas gestionan sus procesos de negocio.


Los Dolores Encontrados en las Empresas
Jean identific√≥ claramente las principales dolores que las empresas enfrentan hoy cuando piensan en tecnolog√≠a ERP:

  • Falta de agilidad para adaptaci√≥n - Muchos empresarios piensan que es muy demorado y costoso
  • Procesos ineficientes y desconectados
  • Falta de transparencia en automatizaciones
  • Preocupaci√≥n con seguridad digital
  • Demora en obtener un sistema actualizado - Un tiempo muy largo para tener tecnolog√≠a de √∫ltima generaci√≥n

Como destac√≥ Jean: "Los empresarios siempre piensan que quieren la mejor tecnolog√≠a de √∫ltima generaci√≥n, m√°s cuando piensan en invertir, piensan que es una dolor de cabeza, es demorado y las mejores pr√°cticas son dif√≠ciles de ejecutar."

GROW with SAP: Las Soluciones
Jean present√≥ c√≥mo GROW with SAP resuelve estas dolores:

  • Implantaci√≥n r√°pida de nuevos negocios y expansi√≥n - Implementaci√≥n muy r√°pida de rollouts para nuevas filiales
  • Procesos alineados con las mejores pr√°cticas globales de la industria - Un sistema "ready to run", pronto para usar
  • Entendimiento de lo que es m√°s cr√≠tico y lo que realmente impacta para automatizaci√≥n
  • Confianza en actualizaciones de seguridad continua en empresa certificada
  • Adopci√≥n de un sistema "pronto para rodar" que crece con el negocio

Dos Caminos: RISE y GROW with SAP
Jean explic√≥ las dos abordajes que SAP ofrece:
RISE with SAP: Para procesos muy complejos, compa√±√≠as muy grandes como compa√±√≠as de petr√≥leo, compa√±√≠as globales con negocios muy complejos.
GROW with SAP: Donde est√°n las primeras inversiones de SAP en el mundo. Es un sistema que puede ser implementado muy r√°pido en las compa√±√≠as. La migraci√≥n para compa√±√≠as que usan Business One es muy m√°s f√°cil porque hay una integraci√≥n muy r√°pida.


Tiempos de Implementaci√≥n: La Gran Diferencia
Jean mostr√≥ datos concretos sobre los tiempos de implementaci√≥n:

  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud: Media de 4.5 meses (1 a 9 meses)
  • Conversi√≥n t√≠pica de sistema: 8 a 12 meses
  • Implementaci√≥n S/4 HANA on-premise (full suite): 11 a 15 meses
  • Implementaciones complejas (full suite): 10 a 48+ meses

Actualizaciones Continuas: Innovaci√≥n sin Proyectos
Uno de los puntos m√°s destacados por Jean fue el modelo de actualizaciones:

Actualizaciones dos veces por a√±o: En febrero y en agosto hay upgrade autom√°tico.
Como Jean explic√≥: "Quien hoy trabaja con SAP sabe que un upgrade es algo complejo, demorado, que muda toda la compa√±√≠a. Hay que pensar en desarrollos Z, programas Z que ser√°n afectados, muchos tests, costo, tiempo..."
En Cloud ERP: "Las actualizaciones son dos veces por a√±o, y el cliente no precisa planear nada. Los updates son autom√°ticos por SAP. Globalmente su ERP, su sistema est√° actualizado en todos los pa√≠ses de una sola vez."
Las versiones siguen el modelo: 2508, 2602, 2608, 2702... sin necesidad de proyectos de upgrade.

Cloud ERP Inteligente: Las Caracter√≠sticas

  • Pronto para usar
  • Actualizado con las mejores pr√°cticas
  • Continua innovaci√≥n hecha por SAP
  • Simplificaci√≥n de tareas diarias
  • Crecimiento de negocios soportado por SAP
  • Seguridad con actualizaci√≥n constante

La Experiencia del Usuario
Jean mostr√≥ la evoluci√≥n dram√°tica de la interfaz SAP, desde las pantallas en blanco y negro del R/2 (a√±os 80), pasando por versiones m√°s amigables de los 90, el SAP GUI tradicional, hasta llegar a la moderna interfaz Fiori donde:

  • Apps organizadas como favoritos - Como en una web o celular
  • Pantallas totalmente customizadas por perfil de acceso
  • Noticias y conexi√≥n con informaciones de la compa√±√≠a
  • Videos integrados en el sistema
  • Total compatibilidad con movilidad - Tel√©fonos, dispositivos m√≥viles
  • Indicadores de Business Intelligence en la palma de la mano

Mejores Pr√°cticas Nativas: SAP Signavio Process Navigator
Durante la presentacion se demostr√≥ c√≥mo las mejores pr√°cticas vienen preconfiguradas en el sistema, listas para activar directamente.
Fit-to-Standard: El Nuevo Paradigma
Jean fue enf√°tico sobre el cambio de mentalidad necesario:
"Las compa√±√≠as van a pensar m√°s en usar SAP Standard, no m√°s tantos desarrollos, no m√°s tantas customizaciones, porque el est√°ndar es pensado, es desarrollado por muchos a√±os para contener las mejores pr√°cticas."
"Los clientes solamente adoptan y usan, no piensan 'voy a mudar ese SAP porque mi negocio es diferente'. Ya viene con las mejores pr√°cticas y los clientes se adaptan a esta fe de no querer transformar SAP con customizaciones que van a demorar, gastar."
La ventaja: "Si tiene un modelo est√°ndar, puede trabajar en Paraguay, Argentina, Estados Unidos, Brasil, Europa con el mismo, sin mudanzas. Y ah√≠ esto es m√°s √°gil y con costo menor."

Metodolog√≠a SAP Activate
fases del proyecto:

  • Discover - Definici√≥n inicial del scope
  • Prepare - Preparaci√≥n para Fit-to-Standard con Business Driven Configuration
  • Explore - Workshop Fit-to-Standard mostrando procesos y scripts
  • Realize - Implementaci√≥n

"Cuando se asigna un contrato, hoy o ma√±ana ya puede usar el sistema. En modelos anteriores, se esperaba 30, 60 d√≠as para tener una base de datos de SAP. Ahora, el contrato est√° firmado y los d√≠as siguientes ya puede hacer un logon en el sistema."

Implementaci√≥n en Paraguay y Argentina: Jean destac√≥ que en pa√≠ses como Paraguay y Argentina, donde no hay localizaciones tan complejas como Brasil, "es mucho m√°s r√°pido". En Brasil, los impuestos son "los m√°s complejos del mundo", pero en pa√≠ses con pocas diferenciaciones de cargos e impuestos, la implementaci√≥n es "muy m√°s √°gil y con menor costo".
El proyecto t√≠pico de Public Cloud es de 4 a 6 meses.
Configuraci√≥n sin SPRO: Central Business Configuration
Jean explic√≥ el cambio fundamental en la configuraci√≥n:
"No m√°s tenemos las configuraciones que conocemos como SPRO. Ahora hacemos configuraciones con CBC, Central Business Configuration."

Extensibilidad con SAP BTP
Opciones de extensibilidad:
Low Code / No Code:

  • Bajo c√≥digo de programaci√≥n
  • Trabajamos en la pantalla moviendo campos con el mouse
  • Custom Fields, Custom Business Objects, Custom CDS Views
  • Custom Analytical Queries
  • Output Management customizado

Pro Code:

  • Posibilidad de crear apps usando APIs e integraciones
  • APIs como "manera moderna de conectar sistemas, hacer customizaciones, volcarlas para web"
  • "Flexibilidad controlada para atender necesidades espec√≠ficas"

Joule: Inteligencia Artificial Integrada
Jean finaliz√≥ mostrando Joule, la inteligencia artificial nativa de SAP que ya viene integrada en Cloud ERP:
"La agilidad, la informaci√≥n va a estar en la mano de ustedes, de usuarios, de gerentes, de directores. En una reuni√≥n de negocios, en un viaje que precisa acceder a los datos, ya est√° todo en la palma de la mano."

C√≥mo funciona Joule:

  • Chat dentro del sistema
  • Consultas en lenguaje natural: "Quiero un gr√°fico de las ventas, cu√°nto estoy facturando"
  • Responde "como personas reales con la inteligencia artificial"
  • "No voy a m√°s buscar un reporte, voy a preguntar: 'Por favor, quiero saber c√≥mo est√° finanzas en abierto, documentos a pagar, cu√°nto se pag√≥ hoy' y viene autom√°ticamente"

El Mensaje Final
Jean cerr√≥ su presentaci√≥n destacando que la informaci√≥n est√° ahora al alcance de todos, f√°cil y r√°pido, permitiendo tomar decisiones de negocio desde cualquier lugar.
La transformaci√≥n es clara: De un ERP complejo y demorado a una plataforma √°gil, con mejores pr√°cticas globales, actualizaciones autom√°ticas, y una experiencia de usuario moderna que pone la informaci√≥n en la palma de la mano.

Agradecimientos especiales a Chess SAP Services por compartir esta valiosa experiencia y al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025 por crear este espacio de aprendizaje.


SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
